column1: Seal Beach is a coastal city in Orange County
column2: California. As of the 2010 census
column3: the population was 24

column1: Seal Beach is located in the westernmost corner of Orange County. To the northwest
column2: just across the border with Los Angeles County
column3: lies the city of Long Beach and the adjacent San Pedro Bay. To the southeast are Huntington Harbour
column6: also part of Huntington Beach. To the east lie the city of Westminster and the neighborhood of West Garden Grove
column7: part of the city of Garden Grove. To the north lie the unincorporated community of Rossmoor and the city of Los Alamitos. A majority of the city's acreage is devoted to the Naval Weapons Station Seal Beach military base.

column2: the eastern area of what is now Old Town Seal Beach became known as Anaheim Landing.  A warehouse and wharf had been built on a small bay where Anaheim Creek emptied into the Pacific Ocean.  It was established by farmers and merchants in the newly-settled town of Anaheim who wanted a closer
column3: more convenient port to ship the wine they were growing and also to receive items they needed to help build homes and buildings in their new town.  For a few years Anaheim Landing came close to rivaling San Pedro for its volume of shipping
column4: but the arrival of the railroad in Anaheim in 1875 made it easier to ship product via the rails than by hauling a wagon overland across 12 miles of soft soil to the Landing.  However
column5: the beaches and surrounding rolling Anaheim Landing had by this time also become popular as a getaway from hot summer days.  Los Angeles newspapers talk of a permanent summer population of as many as 400 and even more on special days.  Throughout the year
column6: the landing was also home to a number of fishing boats that plied the local fishing areas.  This activity was written about by Nobel-prize winning author Henryk Sienkiewicz in a short essay
column7: "The Cranes."   The site of Anaheim Landing is now registered as a California Historical Landmark.In 1903 Los Angeles realtor Philip A. Stanton
column8: very familiar with the area from his time selling land in Anaheim
column9: and Huntington Beach and also from representing the local real estate interests of banker (and Pacific Electric Railroad co-owner) Isaias W. Hellman
column10: put together a syndicate to lay out the town of Bayside on the land between Anaheim Landing and Anaheim Bay and the eastern edge of Alamitos Bay.  The new town would be along the still not-announced leg of the Pacific Electric which would run from Long Beach to Newport Beach.  As there was already a town called Bayside in Northern California (by Eureka) Stanton's group instead called their new town Bay City.  Due to many factors—including competition from other beach resort areas (Long Beach
column11: Redondo Beach and Venice/Ocean Park/Santa Monica)
column13: and the 1906 San Francisco Earthquake which sent most investment dollars to the more lucrative rebuilding of San Francisco—Bay City failed miserably as a real estate investment.  In 1913
column14: Stanton optioned the land to real estate promoter Guy M. Rush who invested in building a renovated pier with pavilions on either side. Rush also re-branded the town as Seal Beach and marketed it via postcards and advertisements around the country.  This too failed and by early 1915 Rush had let his options lapse.  In 1915 Stanton tried again
column15: arranging to obtain some amusements from the closing San Francisco Panama-Pacific International Exposition and rebuild them as part of new amusement area which would be called The Joy Zone.  As part of this plan
column16: the Bayside Land Company led a campaign to incorporate the town (October 27
column17: 1915) and then had the new city council approve legal drinking in the town.  This made it different from the Pike at Long Beach which was a "dry city."  The Joy Zone
column18: a beach-side amusement park built in 1916
column19: was the first in Orange County.  It achieved some brief popularity
column20: but the US entry into World War I and the resulting restrictions on rubber and metal dramatically impacted the amusement area.

column2: Prohibition impacted the town's value as an amusement resort.  After 1920
column3: the town's location on two Bays with many inlets to offload bootleg liquor
column5: and its location on the county line
column6: allowed it to become a popular place for rumrunners and then gamblers.  From 1928 to 1939
column7: the town had as many as six gambling establishments on Main Street.  In addition most of Southern California's famous gambling ships (Johanna Smith
column13: Mt. Baker) operated off the Seal Beach just over the line from Long Beach.  With gambling being a misdemeanor
column14: the trials were held in the town's municipal court and a Seal Beach jury never returned a guilty verdict
column15: to the dismay of Orange County and Long Beach officials.  But around 1941
column16: with significant pressure being put on the gamblers by State Attorney General Earl Warren
column17: most of the Seal Beach and gambling ship ended Their absence was soon filled by a former Los Angeles police detective named William L. Robertson.In early 1944. during World War II
column18: the Navy purchased most of the land around Anaheim Landing to construct the United States Navy's Naval Weapons Station Seal Beach for loading
column20: and storing of ammunition for the Pacific Fleet
column21: and especially those US Navy warships home-ported in Long Beach and San Diego. With closure of the Concord Naval Weapons Station in Northern California
column22: it has become the primary source of munitions for a majority of the U.S. Pacific Fleet.    The arrival of the Navy  catalyzed a growth in population which eventually succeeded in shutting down Robertson's gambling operations.

column1: Surfing has always had a presence in Seal Beach.  Newspaper advertisements showing surfers were part of Guy M. Rush's "Seal Beach" campaign of 1913.  The town hosted the mainland's first surfing competition—it was at a private gathering of the annual Minnesota Picnic.  But its popularity really took off after the war with the arrival of legendary surfer Blackie August
column2: who taught many of the local kids how to surf.  August's son
column3: Robert
column4: was one of the pair of surfers featured in the classic surf film
column5: Endless Summer.  Local legends Jack Haley and Mike Haley were the winners of the first two national surfing championships.

column1: The deadliest mass killing in Orange County history occurred in Seal Beach. On October 12
column3: a mass shooting took place at the local Salon Meritage hair salon. Eight people inside the salon and one person in the parking lot were shot
column4: and only one victim survived. The suspect in the shooting
column6: was arrested without incident and charged with eight counts of murder and one count of attempted murder. Prior to the shooting
column7: there had been only one murder in Seal Beach during the previous four years.

column1: The major employer in Seal Beach is Boeing
column2: employing roughly 1
column3: 000 people. Its facility was originally built to manufacture the second stage of the Saturn V rocket for NASA's Apollo manned space flight missions to the Moon and for the Skylab program. Boeing Homeland Security & Services (airport security
column4: etc.) is based in Seal Beach and Boeing Space & Intelligence Systems (satellite systems and classified programs) is headquartered in Seal Beach.

column1: The Lions Club Pancake Breakfast in April and its Fish Fry (started in 1943) in July are two of the biggest events in Seal Beach. There has been a Rough Water Swim the same weekend as the Fish Fry since the 1960s. The Seal Beach Chamber of Commerce sponsors many events
column2: including: a Classic Car Show in April
column3: a Summer Concert series once every week in July and August
column4: the Christmas Parade in December along with Santa and the Reindeer.  Also in the fall is the Kite Festival in September.  The Taste for Los Al
column5: which since 2001 has been benefitting activities at Los Alamitos High School (home high school for Seal Beach students)
column6: takes place every October and has one of the largest silent auctions in the nation

column1: The record label Mash Down Babylon Records is based in Seal Beach
column2: operated out of a garage known as The Elizabethan. The label was founded by Matt Embree
column3: lead vocalist and guitarist in the Seal Beach-based progressive rock/post-hardcore band RX Bandits.

column1: On Electric Avenue where the railroad tracks used to run
column2: there is the Red Car Museum which features a restored Pacific Electric Railway Red Car.  The Red Car trolley tracks once passed through Seal Beach going south to the Balboa Peninsula in Newport Beach. Going north into Long Beach a rider could then take the Red Cars through much of Los Angeles County.Seal Beach is also home to the Bay Theatre
column3: which was a popular venue for independent film and revival screenings. It was closed in 2012 but was purchased in 2017 by Paul Dunlap who is currently restoring it.

column1: The Seal Beach National Wildlife Refuge is located on part of the Naval Weapons Station Seal Beach. Much of the refuge's 911 acres (3.69 km2) is the remnant of the saltwater marsh in the Anaheim Bay estuary (the rest of the marsh became the bayside community of Huntington Harbour
column2: which is part of Huntington Beach). Three endangered species
column3: the Ridgway's light-footed rail
column6: can be found nesting in the refuge. With the loss and degradation of coastal wetlands in California
column8: including the Bolsa Chica Ecological Reserve in Huntington Beach and Upper Newport Bay in Newport Beach
column9: has become much more important for migrating and wintering shorebirds
column11: and seabirds. Although the refuge is a great place for birdwatching
column12: because it is part of the weapons station
column13: access is limited and usually restricted to once-a-month tours.

column1: The second longest wooden pier in California (the longest is in Oceanside) is located in Seal Beach and is used for fishing and sightseeing. The pier has periodically suffered severe damage due to storms and other mishaps
column2: requiring extensive reconstruction. A plaque at the pier's entrance memorializes Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works
column5: a rebuilding necessitated by storms in 1935. Another plaque honors the individuals
column7: and groups who helped rebuild the pier after a storm on March 2
column9: tore away several sections. A "Save the Pier" group formed in response to an initial vote by the City Council not to repair the pier. The ensuing outcry of dismay among residents caused the City Council to reverse its stance while claiming the city lacked the necessary funds. Residents mobilized and eventually raised $2.3 million from private and public donors to rebuild the pier.

column1: Surfing locations in Seal Beach include the Seal Beach pier and the river-"Stingray Bay" (or Ray Bay—the surfer's nickname for the mouth of the San Gabriel River—the stingrays are attracted by the heated water from several upstream powerplants). Classic longboard builders in the area include Harbour Surfboards
column2: established in 1959
column3: in Seal Beach.

column1: The city is administered under a council-manager form of government
column2: and is governed by a five-member city council serving four-year alternating terms.  The mayor and mayor pro tempore are chosen by and from the council.Seal Beach's municipal jail offers a pay for stay program in which offenders who would normally go to county jails could stay at Seal Beach's jail for a price.
Seal Beach is in the  34th Senate District
column3: represented by Democrat Tom Umberg
column5: represented by Republican Tyler Diep.In the United States House of Representatives
column6: Seal Beach is in California's  48th congressional district

column1: Seal Beach once had its own elementary school district and sent its older children to Huntington Beach or Marina High School in the Huntington Beach Union High School District.  Since the early 1980s it has been part of the Los Alamitos Unified School District. Younger students (K-5) go to McGaugh Elementary School
column2: Hopkinson Elementary School
column3: Rossmoor Elementary
column5: Los Alamitos Elementary or Weaver Elementary. Students in grades 6–8 attend either Oak Middle School or McAuliffe Middle School.  High school students go to Los Alamitos High School
column6: which is a Gold Ribbon School.  Until 2000
column7: the Orange County High School of the Arts was part of Los Alamitos High School.  In 2000
column8: the school district suffered a major blow when the community lost the Orange County High School of the Arts to Santa Ana
